title: Rise in deer collisions expected during autumn rutting season
text:
As we approach the autumn deer rut, when many of the United Kingdom’s 2 million deer are on the move in search of females of the species, it has been estimated that up to 74,000 of the animals are struck by vehicles every year.

That’s according to The Deer Initiative, which says that collisions with the animals are most likely at dawn and dusk – which coincides with the morning and evening commutes.

Areas where deer are most likely to be encountered are usually well signposted – a leaping deer within the usual red-bordered warning triangle.

An average of 15 to 20 drivers die each year after such encounters. A further 1,100 are seriously injured and some 700 sustain less serious injuries.
